laboratory.title: Lab Info｜辻村研究室｜名古屋市立大学芸術工学部
laboratory.outline: We regard life as an information processing system of various stimuli and study the ways in which visual information such as color, shape, and brightness is processed from a neurophysiological and experimental psychological approach.

content: We are focusing on the relationship between sensory information processing, such as color and brightness, and higher brain functions. In addition, we are focusing on investigating the function of melanopsin ganglion cells, which play an important role in encoding external light signals in the brain. Our goal is to answer the question of how processing in the retina is being conducted, integrated and how it is represented in the brain, by using psychophysical and neurophysiological methods. The retina of our eye contains two types of photoreceptors (cone and rod cells).

It has long been believed that these two photoreceptors are the only ones that allow us to perceive and discriminate between objects. However, a third photoreceptor, the melanopsin cell, has been discovered around 2000. Melanopsin cells have a photoreceptor protein called melanopsin. The discovery of melanopsin cells has led to a fundamental rethinking of non-image and image forming pathways, such as circadian rythm and pupillary light reflex.

Melanopsin cells are thought to play an important role in encoding ambient light in the brain. Signals from melanopsin cells stimulated by ambient light, along with signals from classical photoreceptor cells such as rods and cones, contribute to brain function in non-image and image forming pathways.

Our research group was the first in the world to discover that melanopsin cells contribute to brightness perception. On the other hand, the regulation of circadian rhythm, pupillary light reflex, contrast and brightness perception are only a small part of the functions of melanopsin cells, and it is thought that there may be still other functions as well. For example, they may also affect memory, attention, mood, and migraine headaches.

equipments.name: Spectroradiometer
equipments.detail: It measures the amount of physical energy (absolute value) per 1 nm pitch in the range of 380 nm to 780 nm of light visible to the human eye. The luminance, chromaticity, color temperature, main wavelength, etc. are also calculated with high precision from these values. It is used for calibration of various experimental equipment.

equipments.name: Spectroscopic Irradiance Meter
equipments.detail: The CL-500A spectroradiometer is capable of measuring color rendering index, correlated color temperature, chromaticity, illuminance (JIS general type AA class), dark irradiance, tristimulus value, principal wavelength stimulus purity, peak wavelength, and spectral irradiance value (360 nm to 780 nm 1 nm pitch: external output only).

equipments.name: 2D Luminance Colorimeter
equipments.detail: The RTC-21 2D Luminance Colorimeter is a camera that uses an XYZ color system with sensitivity equivalent to that of the human eye, and can acquire color information over a wide color range that cannot be captured by ordinary RGB three-primary color cameras. The acquired wide color gamut and high color XYZ images can be checked, saved and analyzed on a PC.

newsDetail.title: Best Rookie Poster Award at the 61st Japanese Society of Ophthalmological Optics
newsDetail.content: Master’s first-year student Nozomu Mori from our laboratory received the Best Rookie Poster Award at the 61st Japanese Society of Ophthalmological Optics, held in Nagoya in August. His research investigated how melanopsin-containing retinal ganglion cells and cone cells in the human retina contribute to brightness perception.
